Problem:
Analyze a mathematical system where the temperature distribution \\(T(x,t)\\) along a rod varies with time and position, governed by the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\frac{\\partial^2 T}{\\partial x^2}\\), where \\(\\alpha\\) is the thermal diffusivity. Consider an intervention represented by a heat source term \\(S(x,t)\\) introduced at a position \\(x1\\) affecting the system.

Given observation of the temperature distribution \\(T(x,T)\\) at some time \\(T\\) can we determine uniquely the time and location of the heat source intervention if it was applied?
Explanation: Determining the exact characteristics of the intervention, such as the precise time and location of the heat source implementation from the end state \\(T(x,T)\\), is challenging due to the nature of diffusion obscuring the effects of localized changes, and potentially multiple configurations and timings of heat sources leading to similar distributions at time \\(T\\).
